question: Mr. Blume. My name's Max Fischer. I just wanted to tell you, I strongly agree with your views concerning Rushmore.
answer: You don't say. Tell me something. How long have you gone here?

question: Ten years.
answer: Then you've been living in a dreamworld for ten years.

question: He's one of the worst students we've got. We're putting you on what we call sudden death academic probation. It entails that if you fail another class, you are going to be asked to leave Rushmore.
answer: I see.

question: Right.
answer: Dr. Guggenheim. I don't want to tell you how to do your job. But the fact is no matter how hard I try, I still might flunk another class. And if that means I have to stay on for a post-graduate year, then so be it. But if --

question: We don't offer a postgraduate year.
answer: Well. We don't offer it yet.

question: You're not dyslexic.
answer: Well, I'm a terrible speller.

question: Just bring up the grades.
answer: Do you remember how I got into this school?

question: Yeah, I do. You wrote a play.
answer: That's right. A little one act. And my mother read it and felt I should go to Rushmore. And you read it, and you gave me a scholarship, didn't you ? Do you regret it?

question: No, I don't regret it. But I still might have to expel you.
answer: Couldn't we just let me float by? For old times' sake? They want to kick me out, Dirk. The only thing I can do. Try and pull some strings with the administration, I guess. I don't have time for a goddamn tutor. You know my schedule. That's the rumor. What? I tried to get Latin canceled for five years. "It's a dead language," I'd always say. At least I saved Dirk from the horror. Who's Henry James? What does this mean? You mean like smart. I'd like to see a list of all the people who've checked out this book in the past year.

question: My pleasure. I'm just trying to impart some of the experiences I've accrued to help Dirk. There he is now. Nice talking with you, Mrs. Calloway. How'd the math test go?
answer: What math test?

question: I thought you had a math test today.
answer: No. Did you turn in your paper on the Berlin Airlift ?

question: Yeah, I got an extension. I shook hands with her. And I gave her my phone number. He said that? That's a really crude thing to say. That's Dirk's mother. Mr. Blume! It's Max Fischer. How's the concrete business?
answer: Oh, I don't know. By the time you hit 45 you're been fucked over so many times you don't really care anymore.

question: I'm sorry to hear that.
answer: What's the secret, Max?

question: The secret?
answer: Yeah. You look like you've got it all figured out.

question: Excellent! Excellent. Irving? Get some rootbeers for anybody who wants one. I don't want one. OK. Next scene. Frank, you enter stage right with a bag of cocaine.
answer: Hey, Max. How was your day?

question: Hm. I'd say
answer: Hm.

question: I know. Pathetic. Just pathetic.
answer: Well. It could have been worse. You were right more than a third of the time. Of course, you can.

question: For once, will you please try not to look on the bright side?
answer: Sit down and let me give you a trim.

question: Do you think I'm stupid?
answer: No! You're just not very good at math.

question: But I'm failing English and History, too. What, like barber college? No, I love Rushmore. I don't want to go someplace second rate. Besides, it would ruin my chances of getting into Oxford.
answer: I wish I knew how to help you. But I just don't. I'm sorry, Max. You want to see the back?

question: No, thanks. You know how I like it. You think I'm spending too much of my time starting up clubs and putting on plays?
answer: I don't know. It's possible.

question: I should probably be trying harder to score chicks. That's the only thing anybody really cares about. But it's not my forte, unfortunately.
answer: It'll happen, Max. It's just. You're like one of those clipper ship captains. You're married to the sea.

question: Yes, that's true. Hello.
answer: Hi. I like your hat.

question: Thank you. You're a teacher here, aren't you?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: What subject do you teach?
answer: Well, I teach first grade, so I do all the subjects. Except music.

question: And this is your first year at Rushmore, I take it. I see. How long have you been a smoker, if you don't mind me asking? Fifteen.
answer: Since I was your age.

question: You should quit.
answer: You're right.

question: Where'd you go to school, by the way?
answer: Harvard.

question: Really? That's a coincidence. My top schools where I want to apply to are Oxford and The Sorbonne. But my safety is Harvard. Thank you.
answer: What are you going to major in?

question: Well. I haven't decided for sure. But probably a double major in Mathematics and Pre-Med. What was your major?
answer: Latin-American studies.

question: Ah, that's interesting. Did you hear they're not going to teach Latin here anymore?
answer: This was more like Central America. Really? That's too bad. All the Romance Languages come from Latin.

question: They do, don't they?
answer: Nihilo sanctum estne?

question: That's Latin, isn't it?
answer: Yeah.

question: What does it mean?
answer: Is nothing sacred?

question: Sic transit gloria. Glory fades. I'm Max Fischer.
answer: Hi.

question: Is that Latin?
answer: What does your dad do, Max?

question: You were in Vietnam, if I'm not mistaken, weren't you? Were you in the shit?
answer: Yeah. I was in the shit. Tell me something, Max. What do you think of Ronny and Donny?

question: Sure.
answer: No. You're right. They're good kids.

question: What's Sunday?
answer: The twins are having a birthday party. And I'd love it if -

question: Oh, that's right. Yeah. I'm not going to be able to make it to that one.
answer: Come work for me. I mean, I could use somebody like you. I could -

question: I may not be rich, Mr. Blume. And my father may only be a doctor. But we manage. No, thank you. I mean, I appreciate the offer. But I've got everything I need right here at Rushmore. Besides, it wouldn't be fair. Excuse me, Mr. Blume. Nice talking with you.
answer: You're on the team? What wouldn't be fair, Max?

question: Hello, Mrs. Guggenheim. Well, I'm just staying over at Edward's parents' house for now. They're out of town. I think I met that boy yesterday. He introduced himself to me. I liked him, actually.
answer: Miss Cross?

question: He's taking a make-up test.
answer: These guys have tests?

question: Of course.
answer: I thought they just did coloring and stuff.

question: Oh, no. They're good readers.
answer: I'm Max Fischer. We met the other day.

question: I know who you are. How are you?
answer: Fine, thank you.

question: You want to help me feed the fish?
answer: Yes, please. I thought I would just let you know, as per our conversation the other day -

question: Latin?
answer: Right. The Romance Languages. I gave a little speech -

question: I heard about this.
answer: You did?

question: Uh-huh. I understand you made a very convincing argument.
answer: I thought you'd be pleased to hear they're going to continue the Latin program.

question: I'm very impressed.
answer: Thank you very much. You need an assistant? I doubt it. I'm on scholarship, though. Academic scholarship. So sometimes, I get to do odd jobs.

question: My husband went here.
answer: I didn't know you were married.

question: Well, he's dead now. So I'm not actually married.
answer: When did he die?

question: Last year.
answer: My mother's dead.

question: Oh. I'm sorry to hear that.
answer: She died when I was seven. Now what's going on in here?

question: Those were just born.
answer: You really love fish, don't you? How much do these cost?

question: You really love fish, don't you? How much do these cost?
answer: I don't want any alloys. I want steel. You change your mind? You want the job?

question: No. But I've got an idea. And need some money.
answer: Come with me. Let's hear your idea.

question: Rushmore deserves an aquarium. A first class aquarium where scientists can lecture, and students can study marine life in their natural -
answer: I don't know. What do you think, Ernie?

question: A huge aquarium. An entire building.
answer: What kind of fish? Piranhas?

question: That's right. Piranhas. I talked to a man in South America.
answer: Really. So you might have piranhas.

question: We will have piranhas.
answer: What does Guggenheim say?

question: Nothing. I felt I should go to you first.
answer: Why?

question: Because at this moment I feel our best strategy is to keep a low profile. The more preparation I can do, the stronger our case will be when we go to the administration.
answer: How much do you want?

question: $35.000 for the initial plans.
answer: I'll give you $2500.

question: You need any help grading papers or anything?
answer: Max?

question: Uh-huh?
answer: Can I ask you something?

question: Sure.
answer: Has it ever crossed your mind that you're way too young for me?

question: It's crossed by mind that you might consider that a possibility, yes.
answer: Not to mention that you're a student -

question: And you're a teacher. And never the twain shall meet. I know, I'm not trying to pressure you into anything, Miss Cross. I'm surprised you brought it up so bluntly.
answer: I just want to make sure -

question: We've become friends, haven't we?
answer: Yes.

question: Good. That's all that matters to me. And the truth is neither one of us has the slightest idea where this relationships is going. We can't predict the future.
answer: We don't have a relationship, Max.

question: But we're friends.
answer: Yes. And that's all we're going to be.

question: That's what I meant by relationship. You want me to grab a dictionary?
answer: I just want to make sure we understand each other.

question: I understand. You're not attracted to me. C'est la vie. I'm a big boy.
answer: Max. You're fifteen. Attraction doesn't enter into it.

question: If you say so. All I'm getting at is I've never met anyone like you. Take that for whatever it's worth.
answer: I think I can safely say I've never met anyone like you, either.

question: You haven't, have you? You want to shake hands? I'm glad we had this conversation.
answer: Me too.

question: By the way. Are you free? Thursday night?
answer: Free for what?

question: Nah. The old man's on call tonight. Mr. Blume, I'd like you to meet Miss Cross, and I didn't catch this young gentleman's name. I like your nurse's uniform, guy.
answer: They're OR scrubs.

question: Well, they're totally inappropriate for the occasion.
answer: Well, I didn't know we were going to dinner.

question: No, you're not. I just wanted to thank you again for accommodating us. We only expected to be a party of three, but somebody invited himself along. I apologize.
answer: You're being rude, Max.

question: No I'm not. I'm just trying to figure out why you brought this gentleman to my play. And my dinner, which was invitation only. Would you like me to pass you the butter?
answer: What's wrong with you?

question: You hurt my feelings. This night was important to me.
answer: How did I hurt your feelings?

question: Hi.
answer: Were you hiding over there?

question: What's that?
answer: What can I do for you, Mr. Blume?

question: Max wants to see you.
answer: What for?

question: To apologize, I guess.
answer: He sent you here?

question: Yeah.
answer: Are you his messenger?

question: No. He's my friend.
answer: I don't think I should see Max anymore.

question: He's not going to like the sound of that.
answer: I know. But I think I let him get too attached. Don't you think? Tell him I'm sorry.

question: What's your first name?
answer: Rosemary. What's yours?

question: Herman. Oh, yeah. He wrote you a letter.
answer: Thanks.

question: OK. So long, Rosemary. Should we meet somewhere? To talk about Max.
answer: Yeah. I don't know.

question: Well, see if she's in her classroom. Let's wait a few minutes.
answer: What's going on here, Maxie?

question: Coach Beck. Good to see you. This is where they're building the new aquarium. I'm in charge of the committee, if you can believe it.
answer: This is the baseball diamond.

question: Hi, Janet. It's Max Fischer. I'm going anyway. Chop it down, Mr. Chandler! We've got an aquarium to build. I don't give a shit about barracudas. But fuck it. I'm building it anyway.
answer: Max!

question: Nice to see you, Dr. Gugg-
answer: Max! Shut those damn things off! Tell me this isn't happening.

question: Dr. Guggenheim, I'd rather not have this conversation in front of the crew. I'm Max Fischer. I'm a former student of Rushmore Academy, which I recently got expelled from. This is my first time in a public school. And I know you probably think I was born with a silverspoon in my mouth. But I'm no elitist. I think you've got some great facilities, and I'm really looking forward to making the best of it over here at Grover Cleveland. One footnote Are you insane?
answer: Max?

question: Yes?
answer: Hi. I'm Margaret Yang. I'm in Mrs. Whitney's class. I just wanted to tell you I liked your speech. I don't think I've ever heard of anyone asking to give a speech in class before.

question: How unfortunate.
answer: The silver spoon remark might rub some people the wrong way. But I think I know how you meant it.

question: Glad to hear it. Goodbye, Miss Chang. Janet. Max Fischer. Is he in?
answer: Hey, Max. How's it going over there?

question: Terrible. Tell me something. When you talk to Miss Cross the other
answer: I got to tell you, Max. I don't know what you see in her. I don't think she's right for you.

question: What's that supposed to mean?
answer: Well, she's not that beautiful. She's not that interesting. I mean, sure, there's something about her. But I see you with someone-

question: Look, Mr. Blume. Your comments are valuable, but let's get to the point. Will she see me again? Yes or no? I'm going to go see her. Hang on. I'm talking on the telephone. Come on, man. That's rude.
answer: You better beat it, laddie.

question: I hope you fall out of that tree and get stick in the ass, Buchan.
answer: You know, I've watched you, Fischer. Showboat, always talking, picking a kid like Dirk cause his mother's a great piece and then getting nowhere. Like everything you do. Big show. No results.

question: And what do you call getting a hand job from Mrs. Calloway in her Jaguar?
answer: A bloody lie.

question: You think I got kicked out for just the aquarium? Nah. That ain't it. It was the hand job. And I'll tell you another thing. It was worth it. So eat your heard out, mick. I got business to attend to. Or do you want me to go? I'm sorry I embarrassed you at dinner.
answer: That's OK.

question: No, it's not. And please apologize to what's his name for me.
answer: I will. Are you OK?

question: I'm fine. But I miss Rushmore. I miss the seasons. And watching the leaves change.
answer: But it's only three blocks away.

question: I know. I miss seeing you. By the way, what time does the library close? I got an overdue book to turn in. That's your handwriting, isn't it? Not bad. Except it's probably bad form for a teacher to write in a library book.
answer: It wasn't a library book when I wrote in it.

question: What do you mean?
answer: I gave this book to Rushmore. My husband gave me this book in the seventh grade. And he went to Rushmore. So when he died I put it in the library here.

question: So that's who that is. Edward Appleby.
answer: I knew him all my life.

question: I do? How?
answer: Well. Weren't you in the Rushmore Beekeepers? He founded that club.

question: Do you think we can be friends again, Miss Cross? In a strictly platonic way?
answer: Of course, I do. Do you think you can make a go of it and settle down at Grover Cleveland?

question: Yeah. But I need a tutor.
answer: I'll be your tutor.

question: Hi, Max.
answer: Hi. What was your name again?

question: Margaret Yang.
answer: Are you free seventh period?

question: Well, I'm supposed to have guitar lessons. Rock.
answer: You can get out of it. And bring a headshot.

question: Hi, Herman.
answer: How are you, Rosemary?

question: Fine, thanks. I just got home and I'm having a little snack.
answer: Having some carrots. Nice house.

question: Yeah, This isn't mine. I'm' just kind of housesitting.
answer: Didn't Max have anything planned for us today? A trip to the museum or something?

question: Did he? I thought he was rehearsing this evening.
answer: Oh. That's right. His new play. He's going to be in this one, isn't he? He's really making a go of it over at Grover Cleveland.

question: I think he's on track. It's nice, isn't it? You want a carrot?
answer: Yeah. I'll have one of those. Well. Max had said something about us all going to the horseraces, so I'm sure I'll see you soon.

question: Or we could go for a walk, if you want.
answer: Sure.

question: Dirk? Dirk? What's wrong?
answer: I know about you and the teacher.

question: Does Max know?
answer: No. And I don't want him to know. I just want it to stop. Right now. You're a married man, Blume. And you're supposed to be his friend.

question: Look, Dirk. I am his friend -
answer: Yeah. And with friends like you, who needs friends?

question: How was she, Herman? Was she good? I bet she was. Although I wouldn't know cause I never screwed her. Sure, you didn't. And next you're going to tell me you didn't just walk out of her house at two o'clock in the morning. Well, I was in love with her first. And all that crap about, I don't think she's that great, I don't think she's right for you, Max. That was all bullshit, wasn't it? Do you think she's in love with you?
answer: I don't know.

question: Well, I guarantee you she's not.
answer: Look, Max -

question: I saved Latin! What'd you ever do? Sic transit gloria, Mr. Blume. Thank you for meeting me. Would you like a sandwich?
answer: All right.

question: I have tuna fish and I have peanut butter and jelly. I'm sorry it's not something more exotic.
answer: I'll take the tuna fish.

question: Milk or apple juice? You want me to cut to the chase? OK. As you know, Mr. Blume and I used to be friends.
answer: I have no idea what the relationship is between you and Herman. Honestly, I find it very bizarre. I'm not implying anything. You make a very strange couple. It's too bad Herman doesn't have that kind of affection for his own children.

question: Well, I'm sure he does.
answer: No, he doesn't.

question: I know you don't really mean that. From his perspective it's -
answer: Why did you call me?

question: That's what I'm trying to tell you. Gladly. Your husband's fucking a schoolteacher, pardon my French. I thought you should know.
answer: Why are you telling me this? Are you trying to hurt Mr. Blume? Or are you trying to hurt me?

question: I have no reason to want to hurt you.
answer: Then you're trying to hurt Herman.

question: Thanks for bailing me out, Dad. Can you drop me off at Rushmore? I got to go settle a score. What are you doing? Are you crazy?
answer: You're trespassing! This is private property!

question: Wait a minute! Stop! Let's have a truce for a second. I want to talk. What's this all about?
answer: Did you say my mother gave you a hand job?

question: You stupid old fool! I'm trying to win her back! Miss Cross?
answer: Hi, Max.

question: You need any help?
answer: No. I have it. Dammit.

question: Here. Let me see.
answer: No. Please, don't come in here. Look. I'm sorry I hurt you. I'm sorry I love your friend instead of you. But just. Please, Max.

question: You honestly believe you love Blume instead of me?
answer: Yes.

question: You'll forgive me if I won't take your word for that.
answer: Stop. If you don't stop with that ping-pong talk, I'm going to lose it. Do you understand me?

question: Let me go! I got kicked out because of you!
answer: You got kicked out because -

question: Rushmore was my life. Now you are!
answer: That's bullshit! What do you really think is going to happen between us? You think we're going to have sex?

question: That's kind of a cheap way to put it, don't you think?
answer: How would you put it to your friends? Do you want to finger me? Or maybe I could give you a hand job in the back of a Jaguar. Would that put an end to all of this? Please. Get out of my room.

question: Fischer, ya spotty fucker!
answer: Hello, Magnus.

question: Got any hand jobs lately?
answer: No, I haven't.

question: Hey, Dirk! Look who's here. Your stepfather! Waitin' for your mum so he can get a piece.
answer: Your mind is as warped as your ear, Buchan. We got him, Dirk. We got him.

question: Your mind is as warped as your ear, Buchan. We got him, Dirk. We got him.
answer: Max?

question: Hi, Mr. Blume.
answer: You wanted to meet?

question: When?
answer: Right now. You said you wanted to meet to put an end to this nonsense.

question: Oh. Yeah. I was going to try and have that oak tree fall on you.
answer: That big one? That would have really pancaked me.

question: So long Mr. Blume.
answer: She's my Rushmore, Max.

question: Pipe dreams Dad. Nothing but pipe dreams. I'm a barber's son.
answer: Hi, Max.

question: What can I do for you?
answer: I thought I might get a haircut.

question: We're closed.
answer: Well, I just wanted to tell you I'm sorry I threw rocks at you the other day. Merry Christmas.

question: Max stops sweeping and looks over at Dirk. What in the hell is that? OK. Sit down.
answer: Have you heard the news?

question: I doubt it. I don't really follow the news anymore.
answer: Dr. Guggenheim had a stroke.

question: I'll send him a box of candy.
answer: Maybe you ought to go visit him.

question: Hey, amigo.
answer: You look horrible.

question: You don't look too great yourself. Good to see you.
answer: You here to see Guggenheim?

question: Yeah. Your partner told me he was under the weather. OK. If you want to play it that way. You getting off?
answer: I'll ride up with you. Who gave you the shiner?

question: Honestly? I don't actually know. It was either Ronny or Donny. But I can't tell the difference anymore.
answer: Well, he really clocked you.

question: Yeah? Well, kids don't like their parents to get divorced.
answer: I don't blame them.

question: Me, either.
answer: How is she?

question: I wouldn't know.
answer: Why not?

question: Because I haven't seen her in six weeks.
answer: She left you? How come? I thought she loved you.

question: So did I. I guess maybe I am too old for her after all. She's still in love with the dead guy, anyway.
answer: You mean Edward Appleby.

question: Oh, yeah. She's fucked up.
answer: You've already got one going, Mr. Blume.

question: Adios, amigo.
answer: Are you OK?

question: Max! What are you doing here? What?
answer: So sudden. I just -

question: Oh, my God. Are you OK? Come inside.
answer: So this is where it all happens? I wouldn't know. Why'd you dump Blume?

question: That's none of your business.
answer: I know it's not. But I'm a little confused right now. I mean. I thought you dumped me for Blume. Then I hear -

question: I never dumped you because we were never going out.
answer: But it doesn't make any sense. I -

question: Well, I am confused, too. But why don't we just deal with getting you -
answer: Because it would help me if you would talk to me for a minute. And tell me what happened.

question: Well, what kind of person does something like that?
answer: I don't know. He thinks you dumped him because of Edward Appleby.

question: What does that mean?
answer: I don't know. I mean. You live in this room. With all his stuff. It's kind of --

question: I was married to him. Although I will say Edward has more spark and character and imagination in one fingernail than Herman Blume has in his entire body.
answer: One dead fingernail.

question: Right. One dead fingernail.
answer: How'd he die?

question: He drowned.
answer: She got cancer.

question: Lie still for a minute, OK? Is this fake blood? You know, you and Herman deserve each other. You're little children. Let me show you to the door.
answer: That wasn't a very satisfying conversation. All right. Goodbye, Miss Cross.

question: Goodbye, Max.
answer: People hate me.

question: People hate me.
answer: That's not true.

question: Guggenheim tried to spit on me.
answer: You should put your mittens on. You're my friend, Max.

question: I'm sorry about what I said about your mother giving me a hand job. I just --
answer: I know, Max. Listen. I'm sorry I didn't take your hand when Buchan kicked your ass. You should stand up.

question: I'm awfully comfortable. No. But it looks familiar. Do you know Dirk Calloway?
answer: I don't think so.

question: Dirk, this is Margaret Yang. I heard about your science fair project on Action 13 the other day. They said the Navy was going to buy it from you.
answer: Not anymore.

question: Why not?
answer: Because it was fake.

question: What do you mean? Why?
answer: Because it didn't work. I thought it would but it didn't. Not all of it. Just the parts I didn't get right.

question: That's exactly the way I would have handled that situation.
answer: Well. It's nothing to be proud of.

question: But it's true.
answer: You were a real jerk to me. Well. Anyway. Nice to see you.

question: Yeah. Nice to see you, too. You set me up. Not bad, not bad. The child has become the father of the man. We might have to get some hockey skates, Dirk.
answer: I already got you some.

question: Do me a favor, will you?
answer: Sure. What? You sure you don't want to stay here and feel sorry for yourself?

question: I'll take a rain check. Thanks for meeting me, Mr. Blume.
answer: What can I do for you? What's this?

question: That's the Perfect Attendance awards and the Punctuality Award. I got those at Rushmore. I thought you could choose which one you like more, and you could wear that one and I could wear the other.
answer: I'll take punctuality. Thank you.

question: How much are you worth, by the way?
answer: I don't know.

question: Over ten million?
answer: Yeah. I guess so.

question: Good, good.
answer: Why?

question: Cause we're going to need all of it.
answer: She's not coming, is she? Ah, shit, man. What the hell am I doing here?

question: Dammit, Blume! How the hell did you ever get so rich? You're a quitter!
answer: This cost me eight million dollars!

question: I like your suit.
answer: Thanks.

question: Is that velvet?
answer: Sorry you couldn't make it to our little groundbreaking the other day. It's kind of a shame, since he's building it for you.

question: Well, you know, I never asked anybody to build me an aquarium. I'm not sure how that rumor got started.
answer: Hm. Me, neither. You think Edward Appleby would've built you one?

question: Yeah. He probably would've. If he had the money. But the aquarium was your idea.
answer: Well, I gave it to my friend. By the way, I still haven't fucked anybody yet. But I guess that's just the way it goes. Yes, please. And make the order out to Ready Demolition, Tuscon. Make sure these don't get wet. I'll see you at 3:15.

question: 9without stopping)
answer: Fischer! Ya fuck!

question: Hello, Magnus. I'd have shot you in the other ear, but it got blown off a long time ago. Not so fast. I owed you that one. Now we're even. I got a proposition for you.
answer: Shove it up your mother's arse, ya little prick.

question: I've got to hand it to you, Magnus. You've got a way with words. You want to be in a play? I'm not pissing with you.
answer: What's all this shite?

question: Nothing. I just think you're right for the part.
answer: I always wanted to be in one of those frickin' plays of yours.

question: You were incredible tonight, Margaret. You were that poor girl.
answer: Thank you. I loved it when you grabbed onto the bottom of the chopper as it was taking off.

question: That was totally improvised. Can I ask you a question?
answer: Of course.
